CeO2 881.7 [15] Effects of CuO/CeO2 and CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts on NO + CO reaction Jiang Xiaoyuan a ∗ Lou Liping b Chen Yingxu b Zheng Xiaoming a a Institute of Catalysis, The Faculty of Science, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310029, PR China b Institute of Environmental Engineering, The Faculty of Environment and Resource, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310029, PR China * Corresponding author. The catalytic activities of CuO/CeO2 and CuO/γ-Al2O3 in NO–CO reaction increased compared to CeO2 or γ-Al2O3 alone, probably due to the presence of the copper oxide species with low valence and surface dispersion. During the thermal desorption of NO, five desorption species (NO, N2O, N2, O2 and NO2) were adsorbed onto CeO2 and γ-Al2O3 but only four desorption species (NO, N2O, N2 and NO2) onto CuO/CeO2 and CuO/γ-Al2O3. There were two adsorbing states of NO on the catalyst surface, the weak one at low temperatures and the strong one at high temperatures. The overall reaction schemes for the NO reduction by CO can be summarised as the followings: Reducibility and characteristics of CeO2, γ-Al2O3, CuO/CeO2, CuO/γ-Al2O3 and ceria-modified CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were examined using a microreactor-GC NO+CO reaction system and the methods of BET, XRD, TPR, XPS and NO-TPD. The results showed that the catalytic activities of CuO/CeO2 and CuO/γ-Al2O3 were increased compared to that of CeO2 or γ-Al2O3 alone, probably due to the presence of the copper oxide species with low valence and surface dispersion. There were two TPR peaks of CuO/CeO2, a low-temperature peak due to the reduction of highly dispersed copper oxide species and a high-temperature peak due to the reduction of bulk CuO. CuO/γ-Al2O3 had one TPR peak, while the CeO2-modified CuO/γ-Al2O3 had three reduction peaks with one low-temperature peak and two high-temperature peaks. The Cu 2p3/2 (eV) binding energy of 5.0wt.% CuO/CeO2 was 932.79 to 934.11eV, compared to that of CuO/γ-Al2O3 equal to 935.0eV. After added with CeO2, the Cu 2p3/2 (eV) binding energy was 934.1eV, slightly lower than the Cu 2p3/2 (eV) binding energy. During the thermal desorption of NO, five desorption species (NO, N2O, N2, O2 and NO2) were adsorbed on CeO2 and γ-Al2O3 but only four desorption species (NO, N2O, N2 and NO2) adsorbed on CuO/CeO2 and CuO/γ-Al2O3. Two adsorbing states of NO were observed on the catalyst’s surface, the weak one at low temperatures and the strong one at high temperatures. The NO-TPD profile also showed that peak temperatures of NO desorption by the catalysts were lower than that by the supports, indicating that the NO decomposition activity of the catalysts was higher than that of the supports. Keywords CeO2 γ-Al2O3 CuO/CeO2 CuO/γ-Al2O3 NO+CO reaction 1 Introduction Nitric oxide (NO) and carbon monoxide (CO) are largely produced by the combustion of fossil fuels from vehicles and stationary sources, which results in serious environmental problems such as acid rains and photochemical smog. The NO+CO reaction is very important in catalytic control of vehicle emissions [1]. Early studies on NO reduction using copper-containing catalysts have been reported [2,3]. Cupric oxide (CuO) and alumina-supported copper oxides (CuO/γ-Al2O3) have been tested for their catalytic activities of NO reduction in the presence of CO [4]. In recent years, most of the studies have focused on precious metal catalysts for the reduction of NO in the presence of CO [5,6]. The NO+CO reaction by alumina-supported rhodium catalysts doped with ceria or ceria-supported rhodium catalysts has also received high attention [7]. Further, the catalytic activities of alumina- or ceria-supported platinum along with Pt–Rh bimetallic particles have been examined [8]. Muraki et al. [9] examined the effect of La2O3 on NO reduction by alumina-supported palladium catalysts and found that addition of La2O3 increased the reduction activity. However, the employment of precious metal catalysts is limited due to their scarcity and high cost. The catalysts containing transition metals and rare earth elements such as V, Cu, Cr, Co, Ce and La with unique catalytic properties have been considered as a substitute for the precious metals and have recently attracted much interest [10]. Copper-supported catalyst is one of the most promising catalysts in reactions with nitrogen oxides, especially in selective catalytic reduction of NO with ammonia [11] and reduction with CO [12]. The Cu/ZSM-5 catalyst is also a classical one with respect to NO decomposition and selective catalytic reduction of NO with hydrocarbons, although at present it is far from practical application. In this paper, the activities of CuO/CeO2, CuO/γ-Al2O3 and CuO-CeO2/γ-Al2O3 were measured using a microreactor-GC NO+CO reaction system, and their properties were characterised with the BET, XRD, TPR, XPS and NO-TPD procedures. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The supports were CeO2 and γ-Al2O3. CeO2 was prepared by thermal decomposition of Ce(NO3)3 at 650°C for 4h. γ-Al2O3 was provided by Wenzhou Alumina Factory in China and was calcined at 500°C for 4h in air before being used as a support. The CuO/CeO2, CuO/γ-Al2O3 and CuO-CeO2/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by the impregnation method using Cu(NO3)2 and Ce(NO3)3 aqueous solutions of the desired concentrations. These catalysts were dried at 120°C for 12h, followed by calcination in an air stream at 500°C for 2h. 2.2 The activity of catalysts Catalytic activity was determined under the steady state in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (φ=6mm). The particle size of catalysts was 20–40mesh, and 120mg of the catalysts were used. The reaction gas (i.e. feed steam) consisted of a fixed composition of 6.0% NO, 6.0% CO and 88% He (v/v) as a dilute. The catalysts were pretreated using the reaction gas at 500°C for 1h. After being cooled to room temperature, the catalysts were allowed to react with the mixed gas. The reactions were operated at different temperatures with a space velocity of 5000h−1. Two volumes and thermal conduction detectors were used for analysing the catalytic activity. Volume A was packed with 13X molecular sieve for separating N2, NO and CO, and Volume B was packed with Paropak Q for separating N2O and CO2. The catalytic activity was calculated using the following formula: [NO] conv. = [NO] in −[NO] out [NO] in [N 2 ] sel. = 2[N 2] [NO] in −[NO] out 2.3 Measurements The BET surface area of catalysts was determined by N2 adsorption at 77K using a Coulter OMNISORP-100 instrument. H2-temperature programmed reduction (TPR) was done by gas chromatography (GC) method using a thermal conductivity detector. The sample (5–10mg) was activated in an O2 stream at 500°C for 0.5h. After it was cooled to 30°C, H2-TPR was conducted. The reduction gas was a mixture of H2 and N2 at 99.999% purity and had an H2 concentration of 5%. Both H2 and N2 were purified using a 401 deoxidiser and silica gel. The flow rate of the H2/N2 mixture was 18mlmin−1 (β=20Kmin−1). X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were obtained at 25°C using a horizontal Rigaku B/Max IIIB powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation and a power of 40×30mA. The diffraction angles were 2θ (°). The wavelength of the source used was Cu Kα=1.540598Å. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were recorded on an America PHI-550 Spectrometer with Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV). The calibration of the spectrometer energy scale was performed using gold (Au 4f7/2=83.8eV). The C 1s line at 284.6eV was used as an internal standard for correction of binding energies. The accuracy of energy values was ±0.3eV. For the measurement of NO-temperature programmed desorption (TPD), 250mg of fresh catalysts were loaded onto a quartz reactor (φ=5mm), and reduced in the reaction gas (6% NO, 6% CO and 88% He) at 500°C for 1.0h, followed by heating in He at 600°C for 1.0h. After being cooled to 40°C in a flow of He, the catalysts were exposed to a 10% NO–He mixture gas. Excessive NO was removed, and the catalysts were remained in the He flow until no significant amount of adsorbates could be detected. The catalysts were then ramped to 800°C at a linear heating rate of 20°Cmin−1 in the He flow. The effluent gases were analysed with a mass spectrometer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 BET surface area of catalysts As shown in Table 1 , the BET surface areas were 54.712m2 g−1 for the obtained CeO2 and 274.301m2 g−1 for γ-Al2O3. When the amount of CuO loading increased from 1.0 to 15.0wt.%, the BET surface area of the CuO/CeO2 catalyst decreased from 49.902 to 44.798m2 g−1. The BET surface areas of the CuO/γ-Al2O3, CuO-CeO2/γ-Al2O3 catalysts also decreased with the increase in CuO loading. In addition, the BET surface areas of the CuO/CeO2 and CuO/γ-Al2O3 were all smaller than that of supports CeO2 and γ-Al2O3 (Table 1). 3.2 The activities of catalysts for NO + CO reaction The effects of CuO loading on NO conversions are shown in Fig. 1 . At 250°C, NO conversions by CuO/CeO2 catalysts reached 82 and 99.8% when the amount of CuO loading was 1.0 and 5.0wt.%, respectively. However, NO conversions decreased steadily with further increase in CuO loading. Excessive copper resulted in formation of crystalline phase of CuO, causing a decrease in active phase species number and consequently reduced the catalytic activity. NO conversions by CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts at 250°C also increased with the increase in CuO loading, but the conversions only reached 71% when the CuO loading amount was 20.0wt.%. These results indicate that the activity of CuO/CeO2 are much better than that of CuO/γ-Al2O3 and prove that the effects of CuO loading on the catalytic activities are related to the characters and specific surface areas of the supports [16]. More importantly, it was found that addition of CeO2 to CuO/γ-Al2O3 induced a prompt increase in catalytic activity of NO+CO reaction. This was probably due to the interaction between CeO2 and γ-Al2O3, which resulted in a formation of CeAlO3, Cu+ and Cu0 and consequently a high activity of CuO-CeO2/γ-Al2O3. After the CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were calcined at 800°C for 2h, their activities changed badly (Fig. 2 ). The XRD analysis showed a solid phase reaction between CuO and γ-Al2O3, which produced a surface spinel structure of CuAl2O4. The formation of CuAl2O4 was unfavourable for NO+CO reaction. However, addition of CeO2 to CuO/γ-Al2O3 was able to restrain the interaction between CuO and γ-Al2O3 and the CuAl2O4 formation. As a result, the effects of high-temperature sintering were reduced and the catalytic activity was maintained. Table 2 shows the effects of reaction temperature on NO, CO conversions and N2 selectivities for NO+CO reaction by CuO/CeO2 and CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The NO and CO concentrations decreased simultaneously, but N2 and CO2 increased as the reaction temperatures increased. At 50°C, little amount of N2, CO2 and N2O was detected in the reaction products. At 100°C, the amount of N2, CO2 and N2O increased and the conversions of NO and CO increased promptly. A continuous increase in N2 and CO2 but a decrease in N2O was observed at 200°C, together with the conversions of NO and CO being 94.8 and 73.9%, respectively. At 250°C, the NO+CO reactions tended to complete and the N2 selectivities by CuO/CeO2 and CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were 100 and 46.7%, respectively. The results indicate that N2O was formed during the initial stage at lower temperatures, and with the increase in temperature the amount of N2O reached a maximum. Further increase in temperature, however, caused a gradual decrease in the amount of N2O until reaching zero. In contrast, the amount of N2 increased continuously with the increase in temperature. 3.3 XRD analysis of crystal phase of catalysts XRD patterns of CuO/CeO2 catalysts with different CuO loading amounts were shown in Fig. 3 . A diffraction peak of CeO2 at 2θ 28.5, 33.1–47.5° was observed when CuO loading was less than 5.0wt.%, compared to two diffraction peaks of CuO between 2θ 35.5 and 38.7° in addition to the diffraction peak of CeO2 at CuO loading of greater than 5.0wt.%. The diffraction peak increased with the increase in CuO loading, indicating a change of CuO dispersion. After calcination at 800 and 900°C for 2h, the diffraction peaks of CuO and CeO2 were even sharper, i.e. the crystalline of CuO and CeO2 became more integrity. The TPR profiles of pure CeO2 and different components of CuO loaded with CeO2 are shown in Fig. 4 . Two reduction peaks of pure CeO2 were found at 430 and 570°C. We presume that the low-temperature peak was due to the reduction of CeO2 surface oxygen, and the high-temperature peak was due to the reduction of bulk oxygen. In addition, the TPR profiles show two reduction peaks for all the CuO/CeO2 catalysts—the existence of two CuO species. One species represented small and highly dispersed CuO particles interacting with CeO2 at low temperature, and the other species represented larger particle bulk CuO interacting with CeO2 at high temperature. The low-temperature peak was at 210°C at the CuO loading of 1.0wt.%. Increasing CuO loading caused the reduction peak shifting towards the lower temperatures. In contrast, the reduction profiles of CuO/CeO2 catalysts calcined at 800°C were similar to those of the catalysts calcined at normal activation temperatures (500°C, 2h), but the reduction peak only occurred at higher temperatures. When CuO/CeO2 catalysts were calcined at 900°C for 2h, the low-temperature peak changed to a large shoulder and loose peak, likely due to the worsening disperse state of CuO and a larger CuO crystalline. There was a diffraction peak of CeO2/γ-Al2O3 between 2θ 28.5, 47.5° and 2θ 45.6, 66.5° at the CuO loading of ≤5.0wt.% (Fig. 5 ). One diffraction peak of CuO occurred between 2θ 35.5 and 38.7° additional to the CeO2/γ-Al2O3 diffraction peak at the CuO loading of more than 5.0wt.%. After calcination at 800°C for 4h, the crystalline diffraction peak of CuO/γ-Al2O3 became even smaller, and a spinel structure of CuAl2O4 was observed between 2θ 31.3, 36.9 and 37.9° for 10.0% CuO/γ-Al2O3. This may indicate that a solid phase reaction occurred between CuO and γ-Al2O3 at 800°C, which caused the formation of CuAl2O4 from some of CuO and γ-Al2O3. After addition of 2.0 or 10.0wt.% CeO2 to CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the diffraction peak of CuO became smaller or disappeared and the catalytic activity was improved, suggesting a close relationship between the catalytic activity and CuO particles. In order to prove the deduction, 10.0wt.% CeO2 was added to CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts and then calcined at 800°C for 4h. As shown in line 5 of Fig. 5, the CuAl2O4 diffraction peaks became much smaller, indicating that the CeO2 addition restrained CuAl2O4 formation. Lines 6 and 7 of Fig. 5 also show that the CuO diffraction peak was present after addition of 2.0wt.% CeO2 to CuO/γ-Al2O3, but disappeared after addition of 10.0wt.% CeO2. It was likely that the CeO2 reduced the average crystalline grain of CuO and increased the catalytic activity. As shown in the TPR profiles of CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, there was one reduction peak for each CuO loadings of 1.0, 5.0, 10.0wt.% and pure CuO at peak temperatures of 264.6, 276, 317 and 392°C, respectively (lines 1–4, Fig. 6 ). However, the reduction temperature range of CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts became wider and hydrogen consumption peak shifted towards the direction of lower temperatures, indicating that due to the interaction between CuO and γ-Al2O3, a change of CuO dispersion state had occurred. In contrast, although addition of 2.0wt.% CeO2 resulted in only one reduction peak, there were three reduction peaks with the addition of 10.0wt.% CeO2 at 215, 230 and 270°C (line 6). Presumably, the peak at 215°C was caused by the reduction of highly dispersed CuO, and the peaks at 230 and 270°C were due to the reduction of different crystalline CuO particles interacting with CeO2. 3.4 XPS surface analysis The CuO/CeO2 catalyst with a loading of 1.0wt.% CuO had only Ce 3d5/2 (eV) but not Cu 2p3/2 (eV) binding energy (Table 3 ). By comparison, with a loading of 5.0wt.% CuO the CuO/CeO2 catalyst had the Cu 2p3/2 binding energy of 932.79 and 934.11eV, indicating that CuO existed on the CeO2 surface mainly as Cu2+ (934.4eV) and Cu+ (932.6eV). This could be related to the strong interaction between the redox couple (Ce4+/Ce3+) and CuO [17,18]. When CuO loading was more than 5.0wt.% and the CuO/CeO2 catalysts were calcined at 800 and 900°C for 2h, CuO existed on the CeO2 surface mainly as Cu2. Therefore, the state of CuO existence on the CeO2 surface was dependent on the CuO loading and calcination temperature. With a loading of 5.0–10.0wt.% CuO, the CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts had the Cu 2p3/2 binding energy of 935.0eV (Table 3), which was similar to Cu2+ (934.4eV) and the same as CuAl2O4 (935.0eV) but higher than CuO (934.1eV) (Table 4 ), indicating some CuO existed as CuAl2O4 after heating at 800°C for 1h. Addition of 2.0wt.% CeO2 did not change the Cu 2p3/2 binding energy of CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (935.0eV). After the CeO2 addition increased to 10.0wt.%, the Cu 2p3/2 binding energy of the catalyst was slightly reduced to 934.1eV and the CuO existed on the γ-Al2O3 surface mainly as Cu2+. After reduction, the Cu 2p3/2 binding energy of CuO/γ-Al2O3 and CuO/CeO2 catalysts was equal to 932.7 and 932.4eV, respectively. By comparison, the standard Cu binding energy was the same as the binding energy of metal Cu. 3.5 TPD of the support and catalyst surfaces with adsorbed NO After the CeO2 and CuO/CeO2 surfaces adsorbed NO, the thermal desorption process took place as a decomposition reaction, but desorption products were more complicated and usually determined using a mass spectrometer. The adsorption of NO by a CeO2 support surface is shown in Fig. 7 . The mass spectrometer tracking found five desorption species (N2O, m/e=44; N2, m/e=28; O2, m/e=32; NO2, m/e=46; NO, m/e=30). The NO desorption process had three desorption peaks, i.e. three NO adsorbing states on the CeO2 surface—two strongly and one weakly at 160, 360 and 460°C, respectively. The NO adsorption by CuO/CeO2 catalyst surfaces is shown in Fig. 8 . During the NO desorption process, there were four desorption peaks at 70, 135, 150 and 260°C, respectively, of which two were small peaks (one main peak and one shoulder peak), indicating that the NO adsorbed by CuO/CeO2 catalysts surfaces was easy for decomposition and desorption. It was obvious that the desorption peak temperature of NO by CuO/CeO2 catalyst was lower than that of CeO2, which means that NO decomposition activity by CuO/CeO2 was higher than by CeO2. Fig. 8 also shows that the N2O desorption peak was in lower temperature ranges. Namely, the NO+CO reaction produced N2O at low temperatures. In addition, from two examined samples, N2 was never detected, likely due to a very high background concentration of N2 and very low concentrations of NO and N2O. In other words, N2 formed by further dissociation was negligible. Nevertheless, the thermal desorption products of CuO/CeO2 did not produce O2 desorption peak while its TPD process detected NO, N2O and N2. It was likely that NO decomposition produced atomic oxygen (O) that dispersed or entered into the bulk of Cu [19,20]. The desorption of atomic oxygen could only occur at high temperatures. Figs. 9 and 10 show the TPD spectra of γ-Al2O3 support and CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst surfaces that adsorbed NO. After the γ-Al2O3 surface adsorbed NO, the process of NO desorption produced three desorption peaks, i.e. three adsorbing states of NO on the γ-Al2O3 surface, where two weak states were at 110, 340°C and one strong state at 500°C. After the CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst surface adsorbed NO, however, the NO desorption produced only two desorption peaks at 130 and 460°C. The lower desorption peak temperatures of NO by CuO/γ-Al2O3 than by γ-Al2O3 indicate that the NO decomposition activity of the former was higher than that of the latter. Similar to CuO/CeO2 catalyst, the thermal desorption products of CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst did not produce O2 desorption peak while the TPD process detected NO, N2O and N2. In contrast, the thermal desorption products of γ-Al2O3 could determine O2 desorption peak but not N2 desorption peak, while its TPD process detected NO, N2O and O2. These results suggest that the conversion of N2O into N2 needs much higher temperatures. After CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst surfaces adsorbed NO, the mass spectrometer was able to detect the desorption product N2, i.e. the NO+CO reaction by CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. As shown in the TPD data, N2O and N2 were produced at low and high temperatures, respectively. 4 Conclusion CuO/CeO2, CuO/γ-Al2O3 and CuO-CeO2/γ-Al2O3 catalysts had higher activities for the NO+CO reaction than those without CuO addition. The activities were related to the amount of CuO loading and combination of the supports, and are shown as the following order: 5.0% CuO/CeO2<10.0% CuO/CeO2<10.0% CuO-10.0% CeO2/γ-Al 2 O 3<10.0% CuO-2.0% CeO2/γ-Al2O3<10.0% CuO-10.0% CeO2/γ-Al2O3 (800°C, 2h)<1.0% CuO/CeO2<10.0% CuO/γ-Al2O3<10.0% CuO/γ-Al2O3 (800°C, 2h). Different CuO loading and support combinations caused changes in surface area, reduction peaks, Cu 2p3/2 (eV) binding energy and NO decomposition activity of the catalysts. An increase in CuO loading decreased the surface area of CuO/CeO2 and CuO/γ-Al2O3. Two reduction peaks for CuO/CeO2 and one reduction peak for CuO/γ-Al2O3 were observed, compared to three reduction peaks for the CeO2-modified CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. At 5.0wt.% CuO loading the Cu 2p3/2 (eV) binding energy of CuO/CeO2 catalyst displays the properties of Cu2+ and Cu+, whereas at 5.0–10.0wt.% CuO loading the Cu 2p3/2 (eV) binding energy of CuO/γ-Al2O3 displays the properties of Cu2+. After addition of 10.0wt.% CeO2, the Cu 2p3/2 (eV) binding energy was similar to or slightly lower than that before the addition. Species NO, N2O, N2, O2 and NO2 were detected during the thermal desorption of NO adsorbed on CeO2 and γ-Al2O3 supports, whereas species NO, N2O, N2 and NO2 were detected during thermal desorption of NO adsorbed on CuO/CeO2 and CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Peak temperatures of NO desorption by the catalysts were lower than that by the supports, i.e. NO decomposition activity of the catalysts was higher than that of the supports. coredata.dc:description: Reducibility and characteristics of CeO2, γ-Al2O3, CuO/CeO2, CuO/γ-Al2O3 and ceria-modified CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were examined using a microreactor-GC NO+CO reaction system and the methods of BET, XRD, TPR, XPS and NO-TPD. The results showed that the catalytic activities of CuO/CeO2 and CuO/γ-Al2O3 were increased compared to that of CeO2 or γ-Al2O3 alone, probably due to the presence of the copper oxide species with low valence and surface dispersion. There were two TPR peaks of CuO/CeO2, a low-temperature peak due to the reduction of highly dispersed copper oxide species and a high-temperature peak due to the reduction of bulk CuO. CuO/γ-Al2O3 had one TPR peak, while the CeO2-modified CuO/γ-Al2O3 had three reduction peaks with one low-temperature peak and two high-temperature peaks. The Cu 2p3/2 (eV) binding energy of 5.0wt.% CuO/CeO2 was 932.79 to 934.11eV, compared to that of CuO/γ-Al2O3 equal to 935.0eV. After added with CeO2, the Cu 2p3/2 (eV) binding energy was 934.1eV, slightly lower than the Cu 2p3/2 (eV) binding energy. During the thermal desorption of NO, five desorption species (NO, N2O, N2, O2 and NO2) were adsorbed on CeO2 and γ-Al2O3 but only four desorption species (NO, N2O, N2 and NO2) adsorbed on CuO/CeO2 and CuO/γ-Al2O3. Two adsorbing states of NO were observed on the catalyst’s surface, the weak one at low temperatures and the strong one at high temperatures. The NO-TPD profile also showed that peak temperatures of NO desorption by the catalysts were lower than that by the supports, indicating that the NO decomposition activity of the catalysts was higher than that of the supports.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of CuO/CeO2 and CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalysts on NO + CO reaction
